item.title: Crimea’s Leader Moves to Cement Control Over Region
item.description: Crimea’s pro-Russian leader appealed to Moscow for help maintaining order, as President Obama warned Moscow to respect Ukraine’s sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Unidentified gunmen took up positions outside the Parliament building in Simferopol early Saturday.

item.title: With Military Moves Seen in Ukraine, Obama Warns Russia
item.description: The new Ukrainian government claimed that Russia was trying to provoke a military conflict by sending troops to Crimea, while President Obama warned Russia to respect Ukraine’s sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN, MARK LANDLER and ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Armed men patrolled the street outside Simferopol’s airport in the Crimea region of Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: South Korean Leader Assails Japan on Wartime Brothels
item.description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea urged Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan to acknowledge Japan’s 20th century aggressions.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Effort to Delay Terror Trial of a Bin Laden Relative Fails
item.description: The terrorism trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith will not be delayed despite a claim by his lawyers that authorities may have mixed him up with a detainee at Guantánamo Bay with a similar name.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER
item.media:description: Lawyers in a terrorism case have sought testimony from Khalid Shaikh Mohammed.

item.title: Ukrainian Ex-President Speaks Out From Russia
item.description: Viktor F. Yanukovych, Ukraine’s former leader, called on President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to act, but vowed to oppose military intervention by Russia or anyone else.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: Ukraine’s deposed president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, gave a news conference in Rostov-on-Don, Russia, the first time he has publicly appeared since fleeing the violence in Kiev.

item.title: Quick History: Tussling Over Ukraine; Gains and Grave Setbacks for Gay Rights
item.description: The promise and perils of change were evident in the bitter global struggle over equal right for same sex couples.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By SERGE SCHMEMANN
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian woman paid her respects to demonstrators who were killed.

item.title: 2 Ukrainian Mayors Play Different Hands in Crisis
item.description: The mayors of an eastern and a western city face uneasy constituents, one group pulling toward Russia and the other oriented to the West.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Andriy Sadovy of the western Ukraine city of Lviv, speaking to reporters in his office.

item.title: Slum Dwellers in Caracas Ask, What Protests?
item.description: While the middle and upper classes have dug in against President Nicolás Maduro’s government, the poor have in large part stayed away.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters blocking a street in San Cristóbal, in western Venezuela, decorated their barrier like a beach scene.

item.title: Currency of China Continues to Decline
item.description: The renminbi lost 0.3 percent of its value against the dollar on Friday, and it has fallen 1.5 percent this year.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: Shopping for vegetables at a market in Hangzhou, Zhejiang province, China. The renminbi has fallen 1.5 percent this year.

item.title: Korean Scientist’s New Project: Rebuild After Cloning Disgrace
item.description: Nearly a decade after his downfall for faking research, the South Korean scientist Hwang Woo-suk has won patents for his work in an attempt to resume studying human stem cells.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hwang Woo-suk at his lab last month in Seoul, South Korea.

item.title: A Bastion for Israel, Seething Inside
item.description: A dispute over Israel at The New Republic has spilled out of the newsroom and into the public realm, leading to questions over the magazine’s new editorial stance.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER SCHUESSLER
item.media:description: From left, Chris Hughes and Franklin Foer of The New Republic. The magazine has undergone a substantial revamping under Mr. Hughes, the 30-year-old Facebook multimillionaire who bought it in 2012.

item.title: World Briefing: President of Sri Lanka Spurns an Inquiry
item.description: President Mahinda Rajapaksa on Friday rejected calls for an international investigation into accusations of massacres and human rights violations during the final phase of Sri Lanka’s civil war, which ended in 2009.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DHARISHA BASTIANS

item.title: World Briefing: American Envoy to Syria Steps Down
item.description: The United States’ top representative to the Syrian opposition, Robert S. Ford, retired from the Foreign Service on Friday, the State Department said.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: World Briefing: Archbishop of Cologne, Germany’s Largest Diocese, Retires
item.description: Cardinal Joachim Meisner, the archbishop of Cologne whose conservative positions found him apologizing more than once during the years that he led Germany’s largest and wealthiest diocese, has retired, the archdiocese said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Business Briefing: Deal Near to Resume Panama Canal Expansion
item.description: The deal envisions completion by 2015 and would require the canal and the consortium to each inject $100 million.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Shepherd of the City’s Rebirth, Rio’s Mayor Feels the Strains, Too
item.description: Mayor Eduardo Paes, whose political fortunes were rising before the street protests, finds himself at the center of increasingly fierce disputes over Rio’s transformation.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Marizilda Cruppe for The New York Times
item.media:description: "Don’t ever in your life do a World Cup and the Olympic Games at the same time," Mr. Paes recently said. "This will make your life almost impossible."

item.title: The Lede: Latest Updates on the Crisis in Ukraine
item.description: Video of entire news conference by Viktor F. Yanukovych; ousted president’s Swiss bank accounts frozen.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Ukraine's ousted president, Viktor Yanukovych, speaking Friday at a news conference in Russia.

item.title: Hamas Chases Protesters From Gaza-Israel Border
item.description: The group says it is trying to protect those who face Israeli soldiers on the other side of a fence, after two people were killed by Israeli fire this year.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: Obama Warns Russia Not to Use Force in Ukraine
item.description: President Obama warned Russia on Friday that it should not intervene militarily in Ukraine, saying the United States will stand with the world to condemn a violation of Ukraine’s sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: President Obama spoke during a news conference at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Protesters Say They’ll End Blockades in Bangkok
item.description: The leaders of the campaign apologized for blockades of major intersections and promised a new strategy for the protests.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Suthep Thaugsuban, told a dwindling number of supporters Friday night that he apologized for the inconveniences of the blockades.

item.title: Ousted Ukrainian Leader, Reappearing in Russia, Says, ‘Nobody Deposed Me’
item.description: At a news conference, Viktor F. Yanukovych said he had fled his country in fear of his life from thugs who took over the country.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: The Lede: Latest Updates: Tensions in Ukraine
item.description: The Russian foreign minister promised to respect Ukraine’s borders; hundreds gathered outside the Ukrainian Parliament in Kiev.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER and JENNIFER PRESTON
item.media:description: People carried a large Russian flag in Simferopol, the Crimean capital.

item.title: Listening Post: Countering Israel Boycotts, With Glamour
item.description: After refusing to give up an endorsement deal with an Israeli company that has a factory in a Jewish settlement in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, Scarlett Johansson has become a hero to pro-Israel activists.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Scarlett Johansson in Paris on Friday. She is celebrated by pro-Israel activists for her refusal to give up an endorsement deal.

item.title: Court Orders House Arrest, and No Internet, for Fierce Critic of Putin
item.description: A judge ruled that Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s leading opposition figure, had violated the terms of a travel ban from a pending criminal case.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s leading opposition figure, was placed under house arrest on Friday.

item.title: Euro Zone Inflation Stays Low; Joblessness Remains High
item.description: The figures come ahead of a meeting next week by the European Central Bank, which is still weighing whether any further stimulus moves are needed.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY
